title: Debug the flow
content:
You can debug flows directly in Workflow Designer or you can execute the flow remotely in Operations Orchestration (OO) Central.

Remote debugging prerequisites

  • Only users with Remote Debugging permissions assigned from Central can debug flows.
  • You can debug the flows that aren't deployed to Central as long as all the dependencies are available in the Central environment.
  • Make sure that OO Central and OO Workflow Designer have the same version.
  • Check that OO Central and OO Workflow Designer use the same Content Pack (CP) versions (recommended).

Debug in Workflow Designer

To debug a flow in Workflow Designer:

  1. Open an existing flow from the PROJECTS pane from an imported Content Pack.
  2. Click DEBUG to expand the Debugger pane.
  3. Click Start or press Alt + F11 in the keyboard to begin the debug process. Depending on the flow type, a relevant debug method gets executed:
    1. Local debug in OO Workflow Designer
    2. Remote debug to OO Central
  4. Click Cancel  or press Alt + F12 to cancel the debug process.

Local debug in OO Workflow Designer

Review the following points for local debug:

  • The local debug is available in OO Workflow Designer only for CloudSlang flows and operations.
  • OO Workflow Designer enables you to debug flows using breakpoints.

To debug a flow locally:

  1. Open a flow from the PROJECTS pane, and then click DEBUG. The Debugger pane expands.
  2. Click Start  or press Alt + F11 in the keyboard. The debug process begins. 
    1. If you had set up input prompts for the CloudSlang flow, the Input Required dialog appears prompting for input.
      1. For Text based input prompt, in the value box, type in the valid strings.
      2. For the Single Selection based input prompt:
        1.  In the Inputs Required dialog, click inside the value box. The list of options that you predefined at the flow/step level will appear for selection.
          In the below example image, the value_1 is the input field which has the following predefined values: 12, 13, 14, 15, and 16 as options for selection.
        2. To search and select an input value:
          1. In the Type to search box, enter a valid value and then click the search icon. The desired result appears for selection.
          2. Click the resultant value. The value gets selected.
        3. Or, select the value from the displayed options. 
        4. To change the selected value, click the input value box and then select a new value.
          The deselection of an input value isn't enabled.
      3. For the Multi Selection based input prompt:
        1.  In the Inputs Required dialog, click inside the value box. The list of options that you predefined at the flow/step level will appear for selection.
          In the following example image, the value_2 is the input field which has the 21, 22, 23, 24, and 25 as the predefined values as options for selection.
        2. To search and select an input value:
          1. In the Type to search box, enter a valid value and then click the search icon. The search result appears for selection.
          2. Click the resultant value. The value gets selected.
        3. Or, select the desired predefined values from the displayed options. The chosen values are marked as selected.
        4. To change the selected value, click the input value box, and then select a new value.
        5. To deselect the chosen values, perform any one of the following steps:
          1. Click Clear to deselect the chosen values. The values clear but the list of values remains open for selection again.
            For example, from the example image, the chosen values 21 and 25 clear for the value_2 input field.
          2. Click X beside each chosen value. The chosen value clears.
            For example, from the example image, if you click X next to the chosen value 21, then it's removed from the value_2 input field.
          3. At the end of the input value field, click X. The chosen values clear.
            For example, from the example image, the values 21 and 25 clear from the value_2 input field.
          4. Click the chosen values again and then select OK. The selected values clear from the input value field.
            For example, from the example image, if you click the values 21 and 25 again, they get cleared from the value_2 input field.
          5. Click Cancel while the input prompt panel is still open. The chosen values will clear, if there were empty values before.
        6. Click either OK or outside the prompt panel. The chosen input values are saved for further use.
    2. Click RESUME. The flow debugs locally.

Remote debug to OO Central tenant

Before you begin to debug, ensure you have Manage Content permission in OO Central tenant.

If you created a flow or operation using the native content pack or created a hybrid flow, the OO Workflow Designer automatically triggers the debugging process to a remote OO Central tenant.

Legend
Type of flow/operation Description
AFL flow/operation The flow/operation developed using the OO Studio. 
CloudSlang flow/operation The flow/operation developed as code inside an IDE or in OO Workflow Designer. See CloudSlang content documentation for more information.
Hybrid flow/operation The hybrid flow is a CloudSlang flow that contains both CloudSlang flows/operations and OO native flows/operations.

To debug a native or hybrid flow from Workflow Designer to OO Central tenant:

  1. Open an existing flow from the project pane or from an imported content pack.
  2. Click DEBUG to expand the Debugger pane.
  3. Click Start or press Alt + F11 on the keyboard to begin the debug process.
  4. In the Debug to OO Central dialog box, enter the HTTPS connection details of your OO Central tenant environment. The format should be <protocol>://<hostname>:<port>/oo/[?tenantId=<tenantId>]
    For example, https://my.OO.Central.net:8443/oo/?tenantId=123456789
    To avoid the OO Central login screen when triggering a hybrid debug, you can configure the cors.security.origin.whitelist system configuration as a list of a semicolon (“;”) delimited trusted endpoints.
  5. Click Approve in the Approve Certificate dialog box. This imports the OO Central's certificate automatically into the Designer's TrustStore if it's not already imported.
  6. When you debug to OO Central  tenant for the first time, you will see the prompt to enable the browser pop-up window.
  7. Enable the browser authentication to connect remotely with the OO Central tenant, and then click Run.
  8. The flow will get triggered on the targeted OO Central tenant and the actual run will display in a pop-up window.
    1. If the flow or operation has the input prompts set, enter the input values in the Input Required dialog, and then click RESUME.
      The OO native flows and operations step inputs assigned with Add an Otherwise option doesn't execute with alternate values when debugged remotely from OO Workflow Designer; it can get executed with alternate values only when triggered from OO Central.
    2. If the flow or operations doesn't have the input prompts set, continue with step 9.
  9. From here you can resume, pause, cancel, or reassign the flow to a different user. If the run succeeds, a drill down based view on the flow will display. The Run is superseded with the Debug text.
    The OO native or hybrid flow deployed to OO Central tenant will run the steps according to the set worker groups.

Debugging with breakpoints

Set breakpoints to pause the execution of the flow at certain steps. This enables you to examine flow step variables or test flow execution with different variable values. For example, you may want to test that the flow you are authoring is valid, but you don't have the input data for one of the steps yet. You can add a breakpoint on the step and check whether the flow executes successfully with test values.  

You can set breakpoints on any step or substep in your flow. However,  flows that include OO native operations can only run in Central, where breakpoints are ignored. Therefore, any breakpoints are ignored when you debug the flow to OO Central.  

Before creating breakpoints, consider that:

  • Breakpoints aren't saved as part of the flow. The breakpoints that you added during a session don't get restored if you refresh the page or change browsers.

  • The changes you make to a flow/action content aren't taken into account when you resume the flow but the next time that you execute the flow.

To set a breakpoint on a flow step in OO Workflow Designer:

  1. Select the flow step where you want to add a breakpoint, then click Set Breakpoint on the Authoring pane toolbar. You can also right-click and select Set Breakpoint from the context menu. The flow step icon changes to a dotted square   to indicate that the step includes a breakpoint. 
  2. Click Debug    . When the flow execution reaches the step, the flow gets paused and a  "Stopped by breakpoint" message appears in the Debugger pane.
  3. Click on the step above the notification message to display and examine the step values.
  4. Edit the values as required. While the run is paused or at any time after starting the debugging,  you can add additional breakpoints on other steps in the flow.
  5. Click Resume     to continue executing the flow with the new values and any new breakpoints.

Debugging restrictions

  • The Debug icon is disabled for invalid flows.
  • Debugging of operations, decisions, and system properties isn't available yet.

Debugging in a multi-author environment

In the multi-author environment:

  • A user can debug multiple flows at the same time.
  • A user can't debug the same flow while it's still in the debugging process.
  • Multiple users connected to one Designer can debug the same flow in their own workspace.

Debugging statuses

After debugging the flow, you can view the outputs and results of the flow in a Run Tree pane. Select any node in the Run Tree to check the context of that step in the Context Inspector.

The table below explains all possible debugging statuses.

Icon Description
Flow is currently in debugging process
Failure result
Success result
Debug canceled or terminated abruptly
Runtime exception
Custom result
Stopped by breakpoint

Errors and warnings

Errors and warnings are displayed at the footer of the Debug to OO Central window as shown below. Investigate logs of both OO Workflow Designer and OO Central if errors occur.

Related topics

  • For instructions on how to validate flows, see Validate flows.
